name: Python
title: The [Python](https://www.python.org/) cheat sheet is a one-page reference sheet for the Python 3 programming language.

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: The [Python](https://www.python.org/) cheat sheet is a one-page reference sheet for the Python 3 programming language.

cards.title: Hello World
cards.code:
>>> print("Hello, World!")
Hello, World!

cards.title: Hello World
cards.body: The famous "Hello World" program in Python

cards.code:
age = 18      # age is of type int
name = "John" # name is now of type str
print(name)

cards.body: Python can't declare a variable without assignment.

...

cards.title: File Handling
Arithmetic
cards.code:
result = 10 + 30 # => 40
result = 40 - 10 # => 30
result = 50 * 5  # => 250
result = 16 / 4  # => 4.0 (Float Division)
result = 16 // 4 # => 4 (Integer Division)
result = 25 % 2  # => 1
result = 5 ** 3  # => 125

cards.title: Arithmetic
cards.body:
The `/` means quotient of x and y, and the `//` means floored quotient of x and y, also see
[StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/a/183870/13192320)

cards.title: Plus-Equals
cards.code:
counter = 0
counter += 10           # => 10
counter = 0
counter = counter + 10  # => 10

message = "Part 1."

# => Part 1.Part 2.
message += "Part 2."

cards.code:
>>> website = 'cheatsheets.zip'
>>> f"Hello, {website}"
"Hello, cheatsheets.zip"

>>> num = 10
>>> f'{num} + 10 = {num + 10}'
'10 + 10 = 20'

hello = "Hello World"
hello = 'Hello World'

multi_string = """Multiline Strings
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit """

cards.title: Numbers
cards.code:

y = 2.8  # float
z = 1j   # complex

>>> print(type(x))
<class 'int'>

cards.title: Booleans
cards.code:
my_bool = True
my_bool = False

bool(0)     # => False
bool(1)     # => True

cards.title: Lists
cards.code:
list1 = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
list2 = [True, False, False]
list3 = [1, 5, 7, 9, 3]
list4 = list((1, 5, 7, 9, 3))

cards.title: Tuple
cards.code:
my_tuple = (1, 2, 3)
my_tuple = tuple((1, 2, 3))

tupla = (1, 2, 3, 'python')

print(tupla[0])       # Output: 1
print(tupla.count(1)) # Count occurrences
print(tupla.index(2)) # Find index

tupla1 = (1, 2, 3)
tupla2 = ('a', 'b')

len(tuple) → Returns the number of elements.
in → Checks if an element exists in the tuple.
Concatenation (+) → Combines two tuples.
Repetition (*) → Repeats a tuple.
Slicing (tuple[start:end]) → Extracts a subtuple.

print(len(tupla1))       # Output: 3
print(2 in tupla1)       # Output: True
print(tupla1 + tupla2)   # Output: (1, 2, 3, 'a', 'b')
print(tupla1[1:])        # Output: (2, 3)

# unpacking
a, b, c, d = tupla   # Each value goes into a variable

cards.title: Dictionary
cards.body:
```python {.wrap}
>>> empty_dict = {}
>>> a = {"one": 1, "two": 2, "three": 3}
>>> a["one"]
1
>>> a.keys()
dict_keys(['one', 'two', 'three'])
>>> a.values()
dict_values([1, 2, 3])
>>> a.update({"four": 4})
>>> a.keys()
dict_keys(['one', 'two', 'three', 'four'])
>>> a['four']
4

cards.code:
Key: Value pair, JSON like object

### Casting

#### Integers

```python
x = int(1)   # x will be 1
y = int(2.8) # y will be 2
z = int("3") # z will be 3

cards.code:
x = float(1)     # x will be 1.0
y = float(2.8)   # y will be 2.8
z = float("3")   # z will be 3.0
w = float("4.2") # w will be 4.2

cards.title: Dictionary
cards.code:
x = str("s1") # x will be 's1'
y = str(2)    # y will be '2'
z = str(3.0)  # z will be '3.0'

cards.title: Heaps
cards.code:
import heapq

myList = [9, 5, 4, 1, 3, 2]
heapq.heapify(myList) # turn myList into a Min Heap
print(myList)    # => [1, 3, 2, 5, 9, 4]
print(myList[0]) # first value is always the smallest in the heap

heapq.heappush(myList, 10) # insert 10
x = heapq.heappop(myList)  # pop and return smallest item
print(x)                   # => 1

cards.title: Heaps
cards.body: #### Negate all values to use Min Heap as Max Heap

cards.title: Heaps
cards.code:
myList = [9, 5, 4, 1, 3, 2]
myList = [-val for val in myList] # multiply by -1 to negate
heapq.heapify(myList)

x = heapq.heappop(myList)
print(-x) # => 9 (making sure to multiply by -1 again)

cards.title: Heaps
cards.body:
Heaps are binary trees for which every parent node has a value less than or equal to any of its children. Useful for
accessing min/max value quickly. Time complexity: O(n) for heapify, O(log n) push and pop. See:
[Heapq](https://docs.python.org/3/library/heapq.html)

cards.title: Stacks and Queues
cards.code:
from collections import deque

q = deque()          # empty
q = deque([1, 2, 3]) # with values

q.append(4)     # append to right side
q.appendleft(0) # append to left side
print(q)    # => deque([0, 1, 2, 3, 4])

x = q.pop() # remove & return from right
y = q.popleft() # remove & return from left
print(x)    # => 4
print(y)    # => 0
print(q)    # => deque([1, 2, 3])

q.rotate(1) # rotate 1 step to the right
print(q)    # => deque([3, 1, 2])

cards.title: Stacks and Queues
cards.body:
Deque is a double-ended queue with O(1) time for append/pop operations from both sides. Used as stacks and queues. See:
[Deque](https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.html#collections.deque)

cards.title: f-Strings usage
cards.code:
>>> website = 'cheatsheets.zip'
>>> f"Hello, {website}"
"Hello, cheatsheets.zip"

>>> num = 10
>>> f'{num} + 10 = {num + 10}'
'10 + 10 = 20'

>>> f"""He said {"I'm John"}"""
"He said I'm John"

>>> f'5 {"{stars}"}'
'5 {stars}'
>>> f'{{5}} {"stars"}'
'{5} stars'

>>> name = 'Eric'
>>> age = 27
>>> f"""Hello!
...     I'm {name}.
...     I'm {age}."""
"Hello!\n    I'm Eric.\n    I'm 27."

cards.title: f-Strings usage
cards.body:
it is available since Python 3.6, also see:
[Formatted string literals](https://docs.python.org/3/reference/lexical_analysis.html#f-strings)

cards.title: f-Strings Fill Align
cards.code:
>>> f'{"text":10}'     # [width]
'text      '
>>> f'{"test":*>10}'   # fill left
'******test'
>>> f'{"test":*<10}'   # fill right
'test******'
>>> f'{"test":*^10}'   # fill center
'***test***'
>>> f'{12345:0>10}'    # fill with numbers
'0000012345'

cards.title: f-Strings Type
cards.code:
>>> f'{10:b}'        # binary type
'1010'
>>> f'{10:o}'        # octal type
'12'
>>> f'{200:x}'       # hexadecimal type
'c8'
>>> f'{200:X}'
'C8'
>>> f'{345600000000:e}' # scientific notation
'3.456000e+11'
>>> f'{65:c}'       # character type
'A'
>>> f'{10:#b}'      # [type] with notation (base)
'0b1010'
>>> f'{10:#o}'
'0o12'
>>> f'{10:#x}'
'0xa'

cards.title: List Slicing
cards.code:
a_list[start:end]
a_list[start:end:step]

cards.title: List Slicing
cards.code:
>>> a = ['spam', 'egg', 'bacon', 'tomato', 'ham', 'lobster']
>>> a[2:5]
['bacon', 'tomato', 'ham']
>>> a[-5:-2]
['egg', 'bacon', 'tomato']
>>> a[1:4]
['egg', 'bacon', 'tomato']

cards.title: List Slicing
cards.code:
>>> a[:4]
['spam', 'egg', 'bacon', 'tomato']
>>> a[0:4]
['spam', 'egg', 'bacon', 'tomato']
>>> a[2:]
['bacon', 'tomato', 'ham', 'lobster']
>>> a[2:len(a)]
['bacon', 'tomato', 'ham', 'lobster']
>>> a
['spam', 'egg', 'bacon', 'tomato', 'ham', 'lobster']
>>> a[:]
['spam', 'egg', 'bacon', 'tomato', 'ham', 'lobster']

cards.title: List Slicing
cards.code:
['spam', 'egg', 'bacon', 'tomato', 'ham', 'lobster']
>>> a[0:6:2]
['spam', 'bacon', 'ham']
>>> a[1:6:2]
['egg', 'tomato', 'lobster']
>>> a[6:0:-2]
['lobster', 'tomato', 'egg']
>>> a
['spam', 'egg', 'bacon', 'tomato', 'ham', 'lobster']
>>> a[::-1]
['lobster', 'ham', 'tomato', 'bacon', 'egg', 'spam']

cards.title: Remove
cards.code:
>>> li = ['bread', 'butter', 'milk']
>>> li.pop()
'milk'
>>> li
['bread', 'butter']
>>> del li[0]
>>> li
['butter']

cards.title: else if
match case

x = 1
match x:

cards.title: Break
Continue
Range
With zip()
cards.code:
words = ['Mon', 'Tue', 'Wed']
nums = [1, 2, 3]
# Use zip to pack into a tuple list
for w, n in zip(words, nums):
    print('%d:%s, ' %(n, w))

cards.title: for/else
Over Dictionary
cards.code:
johndict = {
  "firstname": "John",
  "lastname": "Doe",
  "age": 30
  }

x = johndict.items()
print(x)

# Output: dict_items([('firstname', 'John'),
#                     ('lastname', 'Doe'),
#                     ('age', 30)])

for key, value in johndict.items():
	print(f"{key} : : {value}")

# Output: firstname : : John
# Output: lastname : : Doe
# Output: age : : 30

cards.title: Comprehension List
cards.code:
languages = ["html", "go", "rust", "javascript", "python"]

newlist = [x for x in languages if "l" not in x]
# add language for language in languages if "l" not in language

print(newlist) #Output : [ 'go', 'rust', 'javascript', 'python']

# List comprehension avoid this :
oldlist = []
for x in languages:
    if  "l" not in x:
        oldlist.append(x)
print(oldlist) #Output :  [ 'go', 'rust', 'javascript', 'python']

cards.title: Comprehension Dictionary
Basic
cards.code:
def hello_world():
    print('Hello, World!')

cards.title: Return
cards.code:
def add(x, y):
    print("x is %s, y is %s" %(x, y))
    return x + y

add(5, 6)    # => 11

cards.title: Positional arguments
Keyword arguments
Returning multiple
cards.code:
def swap(x, y):
    return y, x

x = 1
y = 2
x, y = swap(x, y)  # => x = 2, y = 1

cards.title: Default Value
cards.code:
def add(x, y=10):
    return x + y

add(5)      # => 15
add(5, 20)  # => 25

cards.title: Anonymous functions
cards.code:
# => True
(lambda x: x > 2)(3)

# => 5
(lambda x, y: x ** 2 + y ** 2)(2, 1)

cards.title: Constructors
cards.code:
class Animal:
    def __init__(self, voice):
        self.voice = voice

cat = Animal('Meow')
print(cat.voice)    # => Meow

dog = Animal('Woof')
print(dog.voice)    # => Woof

# => A class variable!

Overriding
Inheritance
@staticmethod
Variable & Parameter

string: str = "ha"
times: int = 3


# wrong hit, but run correctly
result: str = 1 + 2

cards.title: Built-in date type
cards.code:
from typing import Dict, Tuple, List

bill: Dict[str, float] = {
    "apple": 3.14,
    "watermelon": 15.92,
    "pineapple": 6.53,
}
completed: Tuple[str] = ("DONE",)
succeeded: Tuple[int, str] = (1, "SUCCESS")
statuses: Tuple[str, ...] = (
    "DONE", "SUCCESS", "FAILED", "ERROR",
)
codes: List[int] = (0, 1, -1, -2)

cards.title: Built-in date type (3.10+)
cards.code:
bill: dict[str, float] = {
    "apple": 3.14,
    "watermelon": 15.92,
    "pineapple": 6.53,
}
completed: tuple[str] = ("DONE",)
succeeded: tuple[int, str] = (1, "SUCCESS")
statuses: tuple[str, ...] = (
    "DONE", "SUCCESS", "FAILED", "ERROR",
)
codes: list[int] = (0, 1, -1, -2)

Positional argument
cards.body: Indicate all arguments' type is int.

cards.title: Returned
cards.code:
def say_hello(name) -> str:
    return "Hello, " + name

var = "Python"
print(say_hello(var))  # => Hello, Python

cards.title: Union returned
Union returned
cards.body: Means returned value type may be int or str.

cards.title: Keyword argument
Keyword argument
cards.body: Indicate all parameters' value type is int.

cards.title: Multiple returns
cards.code:
def resp200() -> (int, str):
    return 200, "OK"

returns = resp200()
print(returns)  # => (200, 'OK')
print(type(returns))  # tuple

cards.title: Union returned (3.10+)
cards.code:
def resp200(meaningful) -> int | str:
    return "OK" if meaningful else 200

cards.title: Property
cards.code:
class Employee:
    name: str
    age: int

    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age
        self.graduated: bool = False

cards.title: Self instance
Self instance (3.11+)
cards.code:
from typing import Self

class Employee:
    name: str
    age: int

    def set_name(self: Self, name) -> Self:
        self.name = name
        return self

cards.title: Type & Generic
Function
Walrus
cards.code:
values = [1, "text", True, "", 2]
i = 0

# It assigns a value to a variable and compares it in a boolean expression
while (data := values[i]):

    print(data, end=",")
    i = i + 1

# Expected result: 1, "text", True

cards.title: Current date and time
cards.code:
import datetime

now = datetime.datetime.now()
print(now)  # e.g., 2024-04-27 14:35:22.123456

cards.title: Creating specific date/time objects
cards.code:
import datetime

# Create a date object
d = datetime.date(2024, 4, 27)
print(d)  # 2024-04-27

# Create a time object
t = datetime.time(15, 30, 45)
print(t)  # 15:30:45

# Create a datetime object
dt = datetime.datetime(2024, 4, 27, 15, 30, 45)
print(dt)  # 2024-04-27 15:30:45

cards.title: Converting between date formats
cards.code:
import datetime

# Convert a string to a datetime object
date_str = "2024-04-27 14:00"
dt_obj = datetime.datetime.strptime(date_str, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M")
print(dt_obj)  # 2024-04-27 14:00:00

# Convert a datetime object to a string
formatted_str = dt_obj.strftime("%d/%m/%Y %H:%M")
print(formatted_str)  # 27/04/2024 14:00

cards.title: Timestamps and Unix time
cards.code:
import datetime

# Get current timestamp
timestamp = datetime.datetime.now().timestamp()
print(timestamp)  # e.g., 1714188922.123456

# Convert timestamp back to datetime
dt_from_timestamp = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(timestamp)
print(dt_from_timestamp)

cards.title: Date difference and timedelta
cards.code:
import datetime

date1 = datetime.date(2024, 4, 27)
date2 = datetime.date(2024, 5, 1)

delta = date2 - date1
print(delta.days)  # 4

# Using timedelta for date arithmetic
new_date = date1 + datetime.timedelta(days=10)
print(new_date)  # 2024-05-07

cards.title: Generators
Generators
cards.body: Generators help you make lazy code.

cards.title: Generator to list
cards.code:
values = (-x for x in [1,2,3,4,5])
gen_to_list = list(values)

# => [-1, -2, -3, -4, -5]
print(gen_to_list)

cards.title: Handle exceptions
cards.code:
try:
    # Use "raise" to raise an error
    raise IndexError("This is an index error")
except IndexError as e:
    pass                 # Pass is just a no-op. Usually you would do recovery here.
except (TypeError, NameError):
    pass                 # Multiple exceptions can be handled together, if required.
else:                    # Optional clause to the try/except block. Must follow all except blocks
    print("All good!")   # Runs only if the code in try raises no exceptions
finally:                 # Execute under all circumstances
    print("We can clean up resources here")

cards.title: Dispatcher Pattern
